bug.short_desc: [Vista] SSL Recording fails on Windows Vista

long_desc.thetext: When attempting to perform an HTTP Recording of SSL traffic on Windows Vista, the recorder is unable to establish a connection to the server. No security warning is presented (like we normally get due to re-direction through our recorder proxy server). It is assummed that this is due to some new security feature in Windows Vista. At this time, there is no known work-around or code fix approach in hand to address this issue.
Created an attachment (id=55927) Ethereal trace file

Created an attachment (id=55931) Etheral trace file showing entire conversion.
In this recording I used another vista machine (9.37.207.132), who had its IE set to use a socks proxy set to the machine running the recorder process (9.37.207.21). I used this method because in the normal local recording I was unable to trace loopback traffic using Ethereal and was unable to see IE to recorder process traffic.
The results are the same, a IE browser on Vista is unable to record SSL traffic. Interesting enough, we were able to take a non-Vista IE, point it to the Vista recorder process, and record SSL traffic. This seems to point to some sort of security setting on Vista IE stopping this SSL conversion.

It has been found that SSL recording works on Vista using FireFox.
No SSL recording solution found for Internet Explorer at this time. At least this narrows it down to the version of IE 7 that is installed on Vista or some not so obvious settings somewhere that are applied on Vista (as opposed to some blockage by the operating system).

(In reply to comment #3)
Does IE7 work on XP?

Yes, IE 7 SSL recording works on Windows XP SP2.
As far as targeting, I believe we should target the fix for 4.2.2 and hope that we find a solution.
[Duwayne Morris] There is no known fix at this time.
DuWayne has done all the research on this and has ideas on how to fix this. I suggest reassigning this to DuWayne. Reassign to me if you feel necessary.

Found this link on Microsoft.com describing the behavior we see when there is a problem with the server Security Certificate.
http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/IETechCol/cols/dnexpie/ie7_https_imps.asp
Importing the Hyades certificate into IE as a trusted certificate and importing it as a Trusted Certificate Authority was no help.
It is now expected based on this info that the same thing will happen to IE7 on Windows XP. This appears to be strictly an IE security measure that happened first on Windows Vista.

Adding some further behavior notes.
Connecting from IE 7 on Vista to a proxy recorder running on an XP machine gives the same error message on SSL, will not connect, while non-SSL works fine. This is an added demonstration that perhaps IE 7 on Vista recognizes the proxy address attempting to establish an SSL connection and blocks because this is a man in the middle attack.
Connecting to a server without a trusted certificate provides a different error message. It also provides an option to view/import the certificate and to proceed with the connection. So, the problem we have is definitely associated with the specific behavior of a proxy server. I tested this by connecting to a Java SSL server running at my house via an IP address and that uses a certificate I generated for myself with no trusted CA.
Perhaps we can overcome this by adding another layer of indirection with a normally acting proxy communicating through a hidden proxy. This may need to do some IP spoofing to work, just a thought. I don't think the solution is simple unless we can get some help from Microsoft.
Another experiment: Tested SSL to my untrusted site through a regular proxy server from IE 7 on Vista, no problem observed. Added Mark to CC list.

After discussing this defect at length with Dave Scott, it appears there are some actions that can be taken to further investigate. Dave has a more detailed understanding of the Ethereal trace info during the SSL hand shaking process and offered some suggestions to help either solve or at least clarify the nature of the issue further. Stay tuned for further info as it becomes available.

Good news! Details need work to determine the exact problem and find the best solution. It appears that there is a problem with the default choice of cipher suite. Using Advanced Options in IE, disabling TLS 1.0 to force the use of SLL v3.0 allows recording. re-start IE when switching this option. This is a work-around for the moment and I will work on a better solution.

Created an attachment (id=56831) Fix for SSL Recording via Internet Explorer on Vista
Changes are in SSLCheckClass.java

Attached a patch for the change made in SSLCheckClass.java. The initialization of the SSLContext for the IBM JVM was changed to use "SSL_TLS" instead of "SSL" in setting up the proxy SSL Server. The problem was that through whatever fault or changes exist in Internet Explorer 7 on Vista (or a fault in the JVM), there was a failure to agree on an acceptable cipher suite on Vista, thus the connection was closing at the end of the hand shake. The expansion to include both SSL and TLS in the SSLContext resolved the issue.
Checked in the fix for this defect on Friday, Jan 12 after testing on supported JVM's and on Linux and Windows. Plan to file new defects to merge this change into other branches.
Please use this defect to check-in the fix for 4.3.1 and 4.4 (HEAD).

Approval request:
http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/tptp-pmc/msg02850.html
Closing this defect again. A decision was made to create separate defects for merging the fix to this defect into the 4.3.1 and 4.4.0 branches.
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.
Verified.
Closing.

attachment.desc: Etheral trace file showing entire conversion.
Fix for SSL Recording via Internet Explorer on Vista

bug.short_desc: [compiler] add feature to command line compiler to treat warnings as errors

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.0
Steps To Reproduce: Typically, developers will ignore warnings that don't stop the build from working. We'd like to be more strict, and treat all warnings as errors.
More information: Could be done as a cmd line option to the compiler. (We use the compiler through Ant, but it's easy enough to pass cmd line params to the compiler).
Something like:
-warningsAsErrors
What about -error:+unused,... instead ? This would allow you to specify some errors and warnings independently from each other.

Thinking more about it, I dislike the concatenation rule. Current doc says that '-warn:null' sets the warnings to exactly null. Which implies '<whatever> -warn:null' sets the warnings to exactly null. Assuming we adopted the concatenation rule, '-warn:none -warn:+deprecation -warn:null' would equate '-warn:none,+deprecation,null', that would mean null. But '-warn:none -warn:+deprecation,null', which means deprecation+null, would also equate '-warn:none,+deprecation,null'. We would then have two conflicting interpretations of a single canonical form: null or deprecation+null.
I have been tempted to consider that the very first instance of non-signed token would keep the property of erasing before setting. But this does not fly well: -warn:+deprecation -warn:null -warn:unused would be null+unused, and equivalent to -warn:+deprecation,null,unused. But then, the current meaning of the latter form is all defaults + deprecation + unused, for which the new notation would (recursively) require a full adornment like -warn:+deprecation,+null,+unused. Note also that a very remote -warn:full near the start of the command line would impair the erasing power of a -warn:unused close to the end of the command line, and that this notion of 'first instance' would compell to use explicit -warn:none to make a late decision about an exact set of warnings.
Unless a simple doc is exhibited that cleanly accounts for these behaviors, I would vote for the currently documented behavior, slightly augmented to account for the current (code to be verified) behavior of combined pluses and minuses, for which I believe -warn:+x,y,z,-t,u,v equates -warn:+x,y,z -warn:-t,u,v that in turn equates -warn:+x -warn:+y -warn:+z -warn:-t -warn:-u -warn:-v, and which specified behavior does not depend on former -warn directives (the result does, not the behavior). I would in particular strictly enforce that <whatever> -warn:x means exactly x, which implies that -warn:x -warn:y means y, while -warn:x,y or -warn:x -warn:+y mean x,y.

Opened a few bugs to report the strangest cases, that I added to the dependencies for this bug.
Note that active tests admit the following, non-documented equivalence:
-warn:+x,y -warn:-z,w == -warn:+x,y,-z,w
It has no side effect I could think of, and is reasonably intuitive given the doc (that only specifies the left-hand expression), so I'd support our keeping it unchanged.

bug.short_desc: 3.3M4 Access rules for Execution Environments do not honor Eclipse-BuddyPolicy

long_desc.thetext:
I have a bundle that uses J2SE-1.4 as RequiredExecutionEnvironment, but because it uses the Sun comm.jar extension it has set Eclipse-BuddyPolicy:ext in it's Manifest.mf
JDT 3.3M4 tells me that access rules forbid access to the javax.comm packages defined in the comm.jar library which is found in the JRE's lib/ext folder.
But, since my Manifest.mf has Eclipse-BuddyPolicy:ext defined, I believe that it should allow access to any packages defined in jar's from the ext folder. After all I've manually specified it so.
What's making things bad is that I have no idea how I can edit access privileges. And specifying a specific JRE in the project is not an option since my project is team shared. Or can I specify some OSGi "Import-Package" or similar?
If you want to grab the project to test, import the Target Management Terminal Team Project Set (just 4 very small bundles + 5 features) from http://www.eclipse.org/dsdp/tm/development/terminal-anonymous.psf
Moving to JDT/Debug
Moving to PDE.

I checked where the restriction rules come from:
* org.eclipse.osgi*.jar/*.profile defines the packages that are considered part of any given execution environment. * org.eclipse.jdt.launching parses these package lists and generates rules for the various execution environments from it. * org.eclipse.pde.core seems to use these rules and validate them against a given bundle specification.
For me, it looks like pde.core needs to take Eclipse-BuddyPolicy into account and avoid strict rule checking against libraries contributed from the JRE's ext/ folder.
cc Tom for input.

Buddy policy is not usually used to access code that you compile against. There is no guarantee that your buddies will have what you need to compile or run. This is similar to the concept of adding a fragment bundle to the classpath of the host. As a best practice PDE has not allowed that because there is no way for a host to put a constraint on a fragment bundle (forget about the crazy compiler cycles this introduces).
In this case you are adding the ext buddy policy and assuming that the javax.comm packages are always available from the extension classloader on every VM execution environment you run on. This is not an accurate statement of your constraints. In a perfect world you would bundlize the comm.jar and export the javax.comm packages from a bundle. Then you would use OSGi constraints (Import-Package or Require-Bundle) to accurately specify your javax.comm constraints.
IMO PDE should be mute on buddy policies just like it is for DynamicImport-Package. The buddy policy is very similar to the DynamicImport-Package concept in OSGi. It is dynamically calculated at runtime (not resolution time). When you cannot find a class/resource from the standard set of OSGi constrants (Import-Package, Require-Bundle, self, attached-fragments) then we attempt to find a dynamic import or appropriate buddy to load the class/resource from. The bundle cannot count on these packages being available. This is why as a best practice dynamic imports and/or buddy policies are only recommended for reflective type scenarios where code is discovered and loaded dynamically (i.e Class.forName).
I do hope there is an eazy way to configure your project to grant you access to these packages at development time. Even though I do not think this scenario is a best practice.

I basically agree with what you say regarding Best Practices, and in fact we did resolve the concrete issue of javax.comm by using a different source base (gnu.io), packing it into a bundle and using Import-Package instead.
But unfortunately, not every kind of library can be converted into a bundle. The original Sun javax.comm implementation is available as binary only; it cannot be easily redistributed; and it will find its native implementations only when installed as a JVM extension. So as a matter of fact, this MUST live as a JVM extension.
My point is, that though PDE can foster best practices, it should not make development impossible in a situation that does not follow best practices and cannot be changed. In the javax.comm case, the code runs fine (through Eclipse-BuddyPolicy); PDE even shows the library as extension; but the EE enforcement rules throw errors at the user which make development impossible and have not been there before Eclipse-3.3M3 so this is a regression in my opinion.
The only workaround I have found, was to set up the project to use the Workspace JVM instead of the configured execution environment since this disables the PDE EE checker. This approach is not team-shareable and will fail in an environment where multiple different JVMs and Execution Environments need to be configured on a per-project-basis.
Because of all this, I have the following suggestions: * PDE can use the EE checker by default, but there needs to be a mechanism for switching it off since there are use-cases where it is not applicable. * Switching it off only when a specific JRE is selected is not sufficient, since this is not team-shareable. * For switching it off, I see the following alternatives: (a) A UI visible toggle ("validate OSGi Execution Environment") (b) Automatically disable it when Eclipse-BuddyPolicy or DynamicImport-Package is used since in these cases the user manually specified already an EE that is "different than the normal OSGi EE".

Just to be clear:
PDE is not putting access rules on the JRE. JDT is doing that based strictly on the EE specified in the .classpath. EE is a JDT concept. So a workaround for you is to revert the jre entry in your .classpath to one that is not EE-baed.
In the future (M6), PDE would need to step in and tweak those access rules depending on the content of the MANIFEST.MF file. For example, if a bundle imports a javax.* package from another bundle, it should not be visible to it from the JRE anymore (bug 164188).
As for the suggestions in comment 6, we have two options: 1. we could consider them once bug 164188 is implemented OR 2. continue to stay out of the dynamic-import/buddyPolicy game completely, and have the user revert to a JRE container entry in their .classpath file that is not EE-based for that project, as I suggest above.
Tom, what do you recommend here?
I recommend option 2. Stay out of dynamic/buddy game.

As indicated earlier, the problem with selecting a JRE container that is not EE-based is that it is not as easily team shareable.
In our team-shared workspace, we have some projects compiled against J2SE-1.4 (+serial), others against J2SE-1.5 so each project select the EE it runs in.
When we have a specific non EE-based JRE container checked in to the .classpath, each team member MUST have a corresponding JRE container with the EXACT SAME NAME defined in his preferences. There is no fallback / best match mechanism like with the EE.
What's making things worse, is that Preferences for the JRE container also cannot be easily imported from some common location, since importing a JRE container imports it together with the absolute path specifying the location of the JRE. Which means that different sets of common Preferences are needed for Unix and Windows if not more. It's not totally impossible (yes we can ask all developers to install the same version of the JRE in the same location) but it's uncomfortable and error-prone.
I think what we really need is a JRE-container that's specfied to be a given EE (so we get the fallback / best match mechanism from JDT) "plus" additional stuff that comes from the extension mechanism. What about EE: "J2SE-1.4+ext" ?
Or, simply a Preference setting that turns off the new "check EE dependencies" feature of M4 - ideally on a per project basis though a global switch would be fine as well. I really consider this a regression.

I am moving to jdt since they are the ones adding access rules.
Darin, do you add access rules on non-EE-based dontainers?
Martin, let's see that .classpath file please.

Well, the corresponding entry from .classpath is <classpathentry kind="con" path="org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER/org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.launcher.StandardVMType/j2sdk1.4.2_13"/>
You see that the String "j2sdk1.4.2_13" at the end is the exact name of the JRE that needs to be set in the Preferences. If it's not there for some team member it cannot build. So we need to enforce that each team member has JVM's registered with a proper well-known name. This makes upgrading a JVM by a service release uncomfortable (though not impossible).
It's easier when we specify an EE. Then every developer just needs a "compatible" JVM installed, regardless of the name he's using. But this doesnt work with classes loaded from the JVM extension through Eclipse-BuddyPolicy:ext

Before EE's developers had to conform to common naming standards for JRE's when sharing non-default JREs with a team. This is a problem that EE's solved (sharing JRE's based on EE, rather than sharing a specific JRE).
You can add an access rule to your EE based JRE to allow access to the com.sun.* packages. This rule is saved in the classpath file and overrides rules on the individual jars.
For example, you can add a "allow all access" rule like "**/*" on the EE. The rules for the EE are editable on the build path page by expanding the JRE System Library.
Please let me know if this works. I think it should be a suitable workaround - as you can override the access rules just for this project. If so, I think we can resolve this bug as WONTFIX.

I could perfectly live with this workaround, since it does what I'm asking -- giving the user control over the access rules. But unfortunately it failed.
I tried switching my JRE to EE:J2SE-1.4, and adding an access rule: "gnu/io/** -- accessible". I'm getting "not accessible" errors.
I verified that the library, RXTXcomm.jar, is visible in the JRE Runtime list of libraries (being loaded from the JRE ext directory). The library itself shows 93 access rules, but I cannot edit them (edit button disabled). So I edited the ones of the JRE but without impact. The dialog tells me that adding the access rule this should apply to all child JARs, but it looks like it doesn't (at least not for enabling access; perhaps the rule is not prepended but appended?)
IMHO, that's the bug to fix: manually set access rules should have precedence over the predefined ones.

PS when I select a particular jvm, it builds fine. With the EE, it fails. Reproducing the issue is easy:
Given that you have plugin X in your workspace, Export X as a jarfile and place it in the JVM "ext" directory, then close project X in the workspace. Quit & restart Eclipse. You'll see X.jar listed in the JVM (ext directory) but not accessible. Adding access rules doesnt help.

This works for me. I had to make sure that my "default JRE" for the desired "EE" was in fact the JRE that I added the jar to the extension directory in... Go to the "Execution Environments" page to ensure that the JRE selected for an EE is in fact the JRE you added the jar to. As well, we don't refresh JRE ext directories on a workspace restart... you may have to add/remove the JRE so we see the new library in the ext directory (there is a bug filed for that already).

Gee you are right. It failed for me on first try, because I had a wrong version of the same jar in this particular JVM's ext directory. Now it works.
So, the proper workaround is going to Properties / Java Build Path, setting the JVM to use an Execution Environment, and editing the access permissions for the JVM to explicitly allow access to those packages that are expected in Jars loaded through Eclipse-BuddyPolicy (e.g. from JVM extensions from the jre/lib/ext directory).
Since there is a proper workaround for specifying this manually, I'm fine with closing this as WONTFIX.
Thanks for reporting back. Marking as WONTFIX.

bug.short_desc: Linux RAServer with security on fails with a memory error when authenticated from workbench "Test Connection"

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: TPTP-4.2.1.1-200611271752
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Install agent controller on linux 2.6 and run SetConfig and set security = TRUE 2. RAStart 3. From a windows workbench try to profile as a J2EE application - add the linux host and do "Test Connection" 4. After entering authentication info and clicking OK RAServer will crash with a message like:
*** glibc detected *** free(): invalid next size (fast): 0x08505ce0 ***
displayed to the console
More information: - Seems easily reproduceable on Linux 2.6 for example: 2.6.9-34.EL #1 Fri Feb 24 16:44:51 EST 2006 i686 i686 i386 GNU/Linux
- reproduced using the DCI build that contains RAServer 4.2.1.1, not reproduced with tptp download of same version.
- no problem with security off
- error message is not always the same, I have also seen *** glibc detected *** malloc(): memory corruption: 0x08391238 *** just as often.
Samson has helped investigate this and has an idea for a solution.
This problem is a "off-by-one-byte" type of error when allocating memory. The existing code does not take into account that strcat() will need an extra byte for appending a null character.
TPTP 4.4 bug 168705 is opened to track the same problem.
Created an attachment (id=55984) Patch file for HEAD stream
Created an attachment (id=55985) Patch file for 4.2.2 stream
TPTP 4.3.1 bug 171264 is opened to track the same problem.

bug.short_desc: [CCombo] eats selection events if the parent shell is disabled and reenabled on lost focus

long_desc.thetext: When the UI thread is busy, the user cannot interact with it. Mouse and keyboard events are queued until you start reading and dispatching events. Why do you need to disable the shell?

For now, I'm closing this as WONTFIX. I'm not sure what I'm supposed to fix. If you disable a control, then events to the control and all children can't be delivered. Feel free to reopen this bug report with more information.
Would it help to asyncExec() the operation so it would run after the button has been pressed?

Reopening with more information.
The use case is a wizard. We have a CCombo as a CellEditor and we need to perform validation on lost focus of the CCombo. Lost focus will be invoked because the user selected the next button in the wizard. We run the validation synchronously so that the process can complete before the selection is dispatched. If the validation failed the next button will be disabled and the selection event doesn't get posted to the button. If validation succeeded we want to honor the selection. This is the desired effect.
The reason that the shell is disabled is because we don't want to queue events that occur as a result of the user selecting the UI during the lost focus processing. This is mostly done so that if the user got a little impatient and selected the next button multiple times we don't queue up these events and end up skipping pages on accident.
The main reason for logging the bug was because CCombo doesn't behave the same as other widgets. If you apply the same snippet but use a Text the select event is dispatched appropriately once lost focus completes. That's the desired effect here.

Note that Brad claims there is a difference between CCombo and Text focus events. I tried his code with Combo instead of CCombo and the behavior is different. Could CCombo be delivering the focus event at the wrong time?
The bug (as far as I can tell) is that CCombo and Combo behave differently.

bug.short_desc: managing splash screen definitions

long_desc.thetext:
with the changes in the way the launcher works there is some new possibilities as to where the location of the splash screen is specified. In particular, the -showsplash command line arg is used to give the launcher the exact location of the .bmp file to show as the splash. If you don't use this you get the old slow clunky splash display method. Booooo. Of course, specing this location is hard. It would be something like -showsplash plugins/org.eclipse.platform_3.2.100.v20061215/splash.bmp
in the eclipse.ini (before the -vmargs line).
We need something that just works out of the box, is easy to spec in a build and works with the product editors etc.
Andrew, what if the splash is inside a JARd bundle? what do we specify?

I need to do some work to clean this up a bit and have raised bug 173103. Currently the -showsplash foo/splash.bmp in the ini file (or on command line) is only interpreted by the launcher.
The launcher.jar Main.handleSplash still behaves as before, it consults the osgi.splashLocation and osgi.splashPath properties (from the config.ini file). It is capable of extracting a bitmap from a jar.

bug.short_desc: Addition of AGR Architecture Document to TPTP website

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1.The document describing the architecture of the AGR needs to be published on the website.
More information:

Created an attachment (id=55971) Architecture Document
I have attached the document to be published online.

(In reply to comment #1)
All of the AGR packages are internal so we separate the (intended) provisional/public API (e.g. classes required by the extension points) and only promote their use. Our API contract (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/api_contract.html) dedicates that 'internal' APIs are intended for use by that plugin. The target audience for this document includes extenders and consumers and not org.eclipse.tptp.test.auto.gui committers (necessarily) so we need to be clear on what this user group can/should access. The target audience of this type of architectural document needs to be users trying to understand the architecture of the AGR or consumers/extenders that want to extend/augment/improve but are bound to the provisional and public API.
Lets keep the package explanation but make a note of the intended provisional/public API (e.g. classes required by the extension points) with a terse reminder the intended use of 'internal' APIs as defined in our API contract (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/api_contract.html).

In addition to posting this document under http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/test/documents/index.php?, I think it's also wise to post it under http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/index.html (under "Documentation for consumers (developers who extend TPTP)")
Let me know when Paul's concerns are addressed.

Created an attachment (id=56489) The revised architecture document
This updated version excludes the package section.

I've uploaded the document to http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/test/documents/index.php? but I don't have access to include a link to http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/index.html.
Paul, If you have access, please include a link under the "Extending TPTP" section. Use the link label: "Architectural Overview of the Automated GUI Recorder". The document is under http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/test/documents/design/agr-arch/Intro-Auto-GUI-4-3-0.html.

bug.short_desc: Determine impact of launcher changes to build/export

long_desc.thetext:
We need to figure out what pde ui and build need to do for export/build with the new launcher story.
1) org.eclipse.platform.launchers is now org.eclipse.equinox.executable - Cross platform product builds need to account for this change - What impact does this change have on releng in general. We ended up making alot of changes in the releng scripts. Is this just us, or are other releng teams going to have trouble?
2) startup.jar is now a bundle org.eclipse.equinox.launcher along with fragments - builds need to be sure to include the bundle and the appropriate fragment - What about on releng style scripts that launch using "java -jar startup.jar"? Can we do anything about this?

On 2) the main impact for the platform builds is in the launch and running of the JUnit test suites. The changes to scripts are not extensive and can be tested within a day or two (to run a build from end to end with the changes). I have experimented with starting the JUnit tests from the eclipse executable, and the only problems I have encountered so far are with running JUnit tests on the Mac. I can provide more detail on this when the Mac test machine is free.

Andrew, I am assuming the new launcher will work just fine with <= 3.2 builds as well.
So, for example, if we include the org.eclipse.equinox.launcher plugin/fragment into any RCP product (>= 3.0) and we give it the new launcher, it should work just fine. Correct?

Any issues with using the new launcher in an old eclipse are all about the splash screen. Biggest item is that there would be no progress monitor since that is now done using SWT instead of natively. Similarily, without the changes in org.eclipse.osgi and in the workbench, there would be only very limited painting.
so will pde/build provide two execution paths: one for the old story and one for the new for RCP export?

We will likely need to tie the choice of launcher feature to the version of the osgi bundle. In fact, I wonder if the org.eclipse.equinox.launcher bundle should have a Require-Bundle dependency on org.eclipse.osgi.
If they are exporting to an older eclipse, and the old org.eclipse.platform.launcher feature is not available, then we could take the launchers from the running eclipse but should probably have a warning.

I think we are done here.
For the cross-platform export, we now first look for and include the org.eclipse.equinox.executable feature. If not found, we look for the org.eclipse.platform.launchers feature.
In all cases, if the product does not list the org.eclipse.equinox launcher and its fragment(s), we implicitly add them. this way, all existing product files continue to work as-is, and it is analogous to how we have always bundled startup.jar for products.

bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchLauncher] Painting the splash screen while the application starts

long_desc.thetext:
Because the splash screen is now in the same process (and on the main thread) as eclipse (to enable SWT in the splash screen), UI needs to periodically paint the display while the application is starting up until the event loop starts running.
The startup framework handles painting the splash screen during startup until the application is started.

Created an attachment (id=57373) Patch to break workbench init out of UI thread
A patch that punts workbench initialization to a non-UI thread with periodic syncExecs to the UI for startup code that requires UI access. Includes:
StartupThreading class where all startup UI access should occur changes to UISynchronizer that defer all non-StartupThreading UI access until after startup has occurred wrappering of all UI callouts in StartupThreading calls. This includes all calls to create executable extensions so that whatever user code was created on the UI thread previously still is.
I would appreciate as many eyes on this as possible as it scares the pants off of me. The painting of the splash isn't as smooth as I'd like it to be but there may be ways to further isolate the work that needs to be done on the UI thread.

Add me to the "scares the pants of me" column ;)
My two main concerns are:
1) You're breaking a pretty fundamental contract in your implementation of UISynchronizer.syncExec. I.e., the spec of syncExec says "The thread which calls this method is suspended until the runnable completes." But this won't be true during startup. If a caller of syncExec relies on some side-effect of their runnable immediately after the syncExec returns, it may fail.
2) I have an admittedly fuzzy concern about taking a wad of code that has always run in the UI thread and moving it into another thread. Can we be sure all code paths can't possibly attempt accessing the UI? Can we be sure all this code is sufficiently thread safe, or that the unthread-safe bits are only ever accessed from one thread at a time (even this can lead to failures due to thread-local caches). I suspect that after some trial and error the bulk of the expensive work will be called in the scope of StartupThreading.run calls, which will defeat the purpose. I guess the alternative is to leave everything in the UI but sprinkle the expensive parts of startup with "runEventLoop" blocks that spin the loop for a defined period (as EventLoopProgressMonitor does).
Assuming reasonable answers to the above, here are some minor notes on the implementation:
- Potential null reference to sychronizer.started() in Workbench.runUI - since synchronize variable may be null if "avoidDeadlock" is false. (Off-topic: I have no idea why we still support the "-allowDeadlock" command line argument)
- Catching arbitrary Throwable in StartupThreading and caching it in a field is dangerous. I would only suggest passing checked exceptions back in this way. For example, propagating an error like ThreadDeath back to another thread is not good. Not properly handling VirtualMachineError can also be disastrous. I suggest that StartupThreading.run behave exactly like Display.syncExec in this regard - let the failure occur in the UI thread rather than propagating back. It's brittle to cache it in a field and hope the caller does the right thing with the exception - for example EditorManager.restoreState just seems to stick it into a MultiStatus and log it.
- Suggest getting ride of StartupThreading.runWithThrowable for the general reason above of it being dangerous to treat all Throwables in a generic way. Personally I also find StartupThread.runWithoutExceptions to be a confusing name (suggests that it won't cause exceptions). I'd just call the plain one "run".
The code added to UISynchronizer is not thread safe, but needs to be. The ArrayList should be synchronized and read/write of isStarting should also be in a sync block to ensure a stale value isn't being read.

I'll provide a more detailed response tomorrow after I get a good nights sleep under my belt.
1) Mmm. How about instead of queuing up all runnables that aren't startup runnables we instead examine the calling thread and block if it's not either a) the UI thread or b) our startup thread c) some other thread that has declared itself to be a "startup thread" 2) This why my pants come off with fear. :) Fully mapping out the startup routine and guaranteeing we've caught all cases seems a depressing task to me. My initial cut at this inserted event-loop spin code at places I thought looked expensive but it seemed like a foolish task to me. Finding the sweet spots seemed less sensible than hunting down places that legitimately needed access to the UI thread and isolating them.
For the more specific concerns: I noticed the -avoidDeadlock thing after putting the patch in and wondered if we even still needed it. If you don't know the answer to that question I'm not sure who will. Perhaps Methuselah...
UISychnronizer synchronization: whoops! Yah. I think my rationale earlier was that it wasn't needed because calls to sync and asyncExec were on the UI thread (along with started()) but clearly that makes no sense at all.
I'm adding Tod and Szymone for comments on the catching and handling of the exceptions.

I'm fairly certain allowDeadlock was added because we added UISynchronizer very late in 1.0 release and we wanted a way to turn it off if it went drastically wrong. On that basis I would suggest punting it. On the other hand, if we're adding a new scary thing, having a way to turn that off is a nice safeguard.

Created an attachment (id=57520) New patch
New patch that blocks on syncExec calls and handles applicability by Thread tagging rather than special runnable. The StartupRunnable is still there, however, and I'll look into removing it next week in favor of vanilla Display calls and SafeRunnables.

I've reviewed the patch with Boris and committed the code (slightly modified to move the ThreadLocal variable to UISynchronizer instead of Workbench). I'd appreciate it if people could grab the nightly build tonight to make sure that things aren't crazy.
(Lord help us)
Verified in I20070206-0010 but there are known bugs that have appeared regarding error handling and corner cases that should be addressed by M5.

attachment.desc: Patch to break workbench init out of UI thread

bug.short_desc: step actions enabled when multiple frames selected

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M4
* Select mutliple stack frames in the same thread > Step over and return are enabled
This is due to the action enablement logic that test the "command adapter" for each selection to see if the action is possible. In this case, step over is supported in each selected frame so the action is enabled. However, it does not make sense to step over in frame in the same thread at the same time.
We might need to change the command adapters to test if they support a command for multi-selections. But, we'd need to batch requests per command adapter. That is, a command adapter would be queried for each element in the selection that corresponds to that adatper. This way we could support operations for multi-selections in different debug models.

Fixed with bug 168434. Command handlers are now provided with all elements to execute/enable on and its up to the handlers to determine the interaction. Elements are grouped by applicable handler to support selections in different debug models.
Please verify, Mike.
verified, also fixed an NPE that was coming from selecting a JavContendedMonitor item

bug.short_desc: WSE does not open in external browser on Linux

long_desc.thetext:
In some cases, the WSE does not open in external browser when forceLaunchOutsideIDE is set to true. Instead, an error message is issued:
WAB0561E Unable to launch Web Services Explorer. org.eclipse.ui.PartInitException: Could not launch external Web Browser for http://localhost:49373/wsexplorer/wsexplorer.jsp?org.eclipse.wst.ws.explorer=2. Check the Web Browser preferences. at org.eclipse.ui.internal.browser.SystemBrowserInstance.openURL(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.ws.internal.explorer.WSExplorer.launch(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.wst.ws.internal.explorer.WSExplorerLauncherCommand.execute(Unknown Source)

Created an attachment (id=56005) patch for wst.ws.explorer plugin
Here is a proposed patch for this problem.
Andrew, thanks for the patch. Targetted to 1.5.3.
Ready for review and commit, thanks.
Reviewed and committed to R1_5_maintenance and HEAD. Released to R1_5_maintenance, tag v200701102233. Released to HEAD, tag v200701102230.
Verified in M200701181631 on SuSE9. Closing.

This problem is still reproducible on a specific case:
When we try to get an external browser when none has been defined yet (i.e. the platform's first call to IWorkbenchBrowserSupport.getExternalBrowser()), this call fails if it's run from a non-UI thread. The previous fix only pushed the IWebBrowser.openURL() call to the UI thread. We need to do the same for getExternalBrowser().
Thanks Andrew. Please resolve in WTP 1.5.4.

Created an attachment (id=59415) patch for wst.ws.explorer plugin
Apply this patch on top of previous patch.
Ready for review and commit, thanks!
Targetted to WTP 1.5.4.

Requesting approval for fixing this in WTP 1.5.4.
Problem:
When the user tries to open the WSE in an external browser on Linux, it fails when the command is run from a non-UI thread because an external browser cannot be created. This will affect subsequent uses of the external browser (not just limited to the WSE) since the default system browser entry will be missing from preferences.
Workaround:
The user must manually define an external browser in preferences, but the user might not realize this unless they open preferences. Otherwise the user has to restart the workbench.
Solution:
The WSE should take into consideration that it might be launched in a non-UI-thread and need to take appropriate steps to create the external browser using a UI-thread.
Testing:
The fix has been tested on Windows, Redhat and SuSE linux. I opened this bug on behalf of an adopter's test team and the fix has also been tested by them.
Risk:
Only one file is changed and the change is just an extension of what was already fixed in WTP 1.5.3 (see comment #7)
Reviewed by: Kathy Chan (kathy@ca.ibm.com)

Just to clarify that attachment 56005 had already been committed and released to WTP 1.5.3. What's new in WTP 1.5.4 is just attachment 59415. I've reviewed the patch and is bringing this for PMC approval for WTP 1.5.4.

Reviewed and approved for WTP 1.5.4.
BTW - There isn't much else left to move into OpenBrowserRunnable. Have you proven that IWorkbenchBrowserSupport.getBrowserSupport(), which we are still calling on the primary UI thread, does not need to also be moved in the UI Runnable?

Hi Chris,
I took a peek at the getBrowserSupport code, it returns the singleton instance of WorkbenchBroswerSupport, and the constructor for that is just a default empty constructor. There's nothing too scary or UI-ish in there so I think we are covered.
+1 Sounds pretty serious
+1 Good explanation and review.
Checked into R1_5_maintenance. Released to R1.5.4 as v200703212342. Will release to HEAD later on today.
Checked into HEAD. Released to WTP 2.0 as v200703220008.
Released to HEAD and R1_5_maintenance.

(In reply to comment #17) > +1 Good explanation and review. >
+1

bug.short_desc: Mac OS X launcher doesn't need 'LSBackgroundOnly' in Info.plist any more

long_desc.thetext:
(This should be filed for whichever component deals with the Mac launcher ... I'm guessing runtime, but it's probably releng knowing my luck at guessing correctly)
Mac OS X 10.4.8 with Eclipse 3.3M4; finally, a dockable Eclipse.app! Hooray! (Now, if only bug 57349 was fixed, we'd have a real Eclipse RCP for the Mac ...)
Now that we've got this (i.e. launching the VM via JNI rather than external process) you don't need to have the LSBackgroundOnly set to 1 for the Info.plist (Eclipse.app/Contents/Resources/). That was there to prevent the first process from showing up in the dock whilst the second process was coming up; since there only is one process now, you don't need to have this. (It actually only stops the Eclipse app bouncing when starting so it's a minor issue)
One weird thing I've noticed; when you double click on Eclipse.app again in Finder, it should bring an already-running Eclipse.app forwards, but this doesn't appear to happen. I'm not sure if this is caused by the existence of the LSBackgroundOnly in the Info.plist or whether it's something else.
Obviously this is Mac OS X specific, but shouldn't be hardware specific.
Can this be fixed for M5? It's a trivial fix.
Sure.
For my edification, where is the Info.plist? I searched through all manners of places via viewcvs to no avail ...
In the new org.eclipse.equinox.executable project.

bug.short_desc: The highlight mechanism of list do not take effact after sorting the list[0001]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Enhancement: the highlight mechanism of list[0001]
Build number: 2.2.0.v20061220-0630
Steps to reproduce: 1. New a datasource (jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://spmdb/gui)and a dataset with table "Account" 2. Add a list binding with the dataset and drag the account_id column into the list detail row. 3. In property editor, insert a highlight: dataSetRow["account_id"] Equal to 1 4. Preview the results 5. Insert a sorting key: row["account_id"] Descending. 6. Preview the results
Actual results: After step6: the highlight has no effect.
Now the highlight of list only can take effect when the highlight condition match the data of first row. But after we change the sorting of the data. The highlight rule is no effect. I think it is not good, let me describe another scenario: One user create the highlight rule like I did, and then he insert a new data which is before the other old data, then he preview the results. He will find there is no highlight, and he will very confused to that. So I think our highlight mechanism should enhance or change.

The highlight of the list only test the first row of the dataset. The highlight of the group only test the first row of the group. The highlight of the detail band will test for each row in the dataset.
I think you should use the highlight in the detail band in this case.
close

bug.short_desc: Multi search dialog popup at the same time

long_desc.thetext:
This is a new feature problem only occurs on EPF 1.1 build, since the fix of bug 163737 is delivered.
Steps: 1. Start EPF 1.1 and open a RTE 2. Press Ctrl+F, the search dlg popup 3. Don't close this dialog, focus back to RTE 4. Press Ctrl+F again, another search dialog popup

Created an attachment (id=56799) patch for fix
Each RichText field has its own Find/Replace dialog. Therefore it is possible to have multiple find dialogs open, but each one is attached to a different RTE. Hitting Ctrl-F in a RTE that has an already-open dialog will change the focus to that RTE's dialog.
patch applied
Fix is verified on build EPF 1.1 v20070115-1615.

bug.short_desc: It's not able to get the line number of EmbeddedImage, Theme and Library in XML source

long_desc.thetext:
This defect appears in the feature brought by plugin:"org.eclipse.birt.report.designer.ui.editor.xml.wtp". After selecting a report element on design outline page, it will jump to the start line of the selected one on XML source editor.
Currently, if a embedded image, or a theme, or a library in report design (or report library, or report template) is selected, model isn't able to return the start line number to UI to set highlight on XML editor.
But, the theme element's line number can be fetched if it is selected in rptlibrary

Currently, we just support get line number for a design element, that is, a table, a label, etc. An embedded image is actually a structure internally, but not an element. So do included libraries in report design.
As for theme, it is a property that indicating which theme the report is gonna reference. The theme entity is in some library which is included by the report. What does Desinger expect the behavior to be? Opening the library and jump to the theme in the library source?

Uploaded codes to local cvs. Will merge codes to global cvs once the connection to internet is ok.
Deprecated a method ModuleHandle::getLineNoById(long id), added a new method ModuleHandle::getLineNo(Object obj)
Designer should update the new API. Thanks.

Designer updated to use the new API, I think the sync. on selecting embeddedimage, theme, library, table row/cell, chart are supported.

bug.short_desc: Unused imports and unnecessary semicolons

long_desc.thetext:
the plug-ins in pde-incubator contain several unused imports and unnecessary colons.
These two flags are used during the releng build and therefore pollute the build results if found. Therefore, they should be removed.
We typically raise the severity level of all flags used by releng to ERROR in the project preferences to easily spot them and avoid polluting the build results.
I have fixed removed the unused deps. I don't know what you mean about unnecessary colons. I assume you mean in the manifest.mf, but this was auto-generated.
sorry I meant unnecessary 'semicolons', e.g. line 491 in GraphModelNode

ok, it should be fixed now. thanks for catching this.

bug.short_desc: Cannot start eclipse.exe: VM not found

long_desc.thetext:
I20061219-1300 (works in 3.3 M4)
Looks like the new story no longer finds java.exe
My shortcut to eclipse.exe specifies:
C:\eclipse\drops\I20061219-1300\eclipse.exe -data workspace -vm C:\JavaSDKs\jdk1.4.2_12\bin\java.exe
This shortcut used to work for years but now it is broken.
Created an attachment (id=55943) The error dialog

The following command line seems to work for me on Windows XP: eclipse -Xms50M -Xmx512M -XX:MaxPermSize=128m -vm C:\devel\jdk1.5.0_10-b03\bin\java -showlocation -data C:\workspaces\eclipse-sh3
but not on Windows Vista where I get a message '.. no Java VM found ... on C:\devel\jdk1.5.0_10-b03\bin\java'
On Vista even double-clicking eclipse.exe doesn't work anymore (without specifying a VM).

Daniel, can you tell me more about your vm.
The launcher is looking (on windows) for the jvm.dll library. To find it we look in some known locations relative to the java.exe. These locations currently are: j9vm\jvm.dll client\jvm.dll server\jvm.dll classic\jvm.dll
I think the problem here is that we are expecting the java.exe on windows to be in the jre/bin directory in order to find the jre/bin/*/jvm.dll.
If you change your link to point to the jvm.dll like -vm C:\JavaSDKs\jdk1.4.2_12\jre\bin\client\jvm.dll does it work?

I use C:\JavaSDKs\jdk1.4.2_12
I found out that using -vm C:\JavaSDKs\jdk1.4.2_12\jre\bin\java.exe
almost works i.e. I can start but Ctrl+Break to get stack traces doesn't work.

I will update the launcher to account for when the exe is in java\bin instead of java\jre\bin.
Can you please open a separate bug for the ctrl+break and what your expected behaviour is there? (Are you hitting ctrl+break on the splash? in a console? Are you expecting java stack traces?)
When using a Windows Shortcut a dialog opens. This used to work since 1.0. I can create another bug but for me this essential to switch to the new story/build.

Fixed finding the VM in HEAD.
Daniel, as a work around for any problems you have, it is possible to use an old launcher: copy the org.eclipse.equinox.launcher jar into the root and name it startup.jar. Then an old launcher will work and the Main class will still load the library from the launcher fragment to do the splash screen. Java will be started in a separate process, similar to starting with java -jar directly.

Thanks Andrew. I fixed the problem and my scripts by simply replacing startup.jar with plugins\org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_*.jar
This way I don't have to go and change all my script and I know what's going on.
I see same problem on my Linux box this morning with I20070109-1805 build. Do you want me to reopen this bug and set OS to 'All' or open a new one on 'Linux' OS?

Can you open a new bug Frdric, this is very much platform and vm specific.
Is this a Sun VM? We are looking for libjvm.so. For Sun on linux, we look in jre/lib/<ARCH>/<client | server>. We could be getting the ARCH wrong, for x86 we would be using i386.
Otherwise, is the java executable that we would be starting from (on the path, or from -vm) not actually inside a jdk/jre (after resolving symlinks)? If it was for example a script, then the only thing we could do is exec the script (bug 168775)
Frdric, please add me as cc if you create a new bug.

bug.short_desc: Mylar fails if the default locale is Turkish due to i and I are different characters in Turkish Locale

long_desc.thetext:
Mylar heavily uses String.toLowerCase() and String.toUpperCase(). In turkish locale, latin i and I are not the same letters. They have different small and capital form as two completely different letters. Therefore after conversions to upper or lower case, equals() method fails if the default locale is Turkish.
I recommend using the locale.ENGLISH in all calls to String.toUpperCase() and String.toLowerCase().

Created an attachment (id=55948) mylar/context/zip
factor all access to toLowerCase() and toUpperCase() to use Locale.ENGLISH as the locale to use during conversion

Created an attachment (id=55949) mylar/context/zip

bug.short_desc: [assist] Content assist displays arg0, arg1, arg2, .. instead of real argument names

long_desc.thetext:
Content assist displays arg0, arg1, arg2, .. instead of real argument names.
This doest not happen when we have a JAR with SRC attached. But anyway argument names should be read from byte code (JAR) and SRC must not be required for this.
This bug was found on versions 3.3, 3.2 and 3.2.1.

Created an attachment (id=55953) Sceen shot of Eclipse "Auto Complete" feature
Sceen shot of Eclipse "Auto Complete" feature -Eclipse JDK = JDK1.5.0_07 -Spring JAR was added to the project, but without SOURCE -no real argument names (just arg0, arg1, ...)

This bug should be closed invalid.
If the Spring Jar doesn't contain source and/or javadoc attachment, the auto-complete functionality will just guess the names arg0..argN.
The .class files do not contain argument names; they contain argument positions. It is not possible to calculate names for them in this case. However, I believe that there's an option (guess argument names?) when there's no source attached that just uses a guess on the class name.

> The .class files do not contain argument names; they contain argument > positions. It is not possible to calculate names for them in this case. > However, I believe that there's an option (guess argument names?) when there's > no source attached that just uses a guess on the class name.
Hey man, are you kidding??? From what time .CLASS does NOT contain method names? Have you ever tried decompiling .CLASS files using JAD for example? Have you ever used more intellectual IDE that know parameter names from somewhere (do you think those IDE are guessing?). Have you ever read JVM Class file specification - http://java.sun.com/docs/books/vmspec/2nd-edition/html/ClassFile.doc.html? Have you ever just looked inside of .CLASS file? If you still does not believe than what is the role of "configLocation" from the following fragment: " this DLorg/springframework/context/support/ClassPathXmlApplicationContext; configLocation Ljava/lang/String; "
Respect,

who know.. probably you are right. Looks like I was wrong. Sorry, man.
Anyway, could it be retrieved from javadoc annotations "/**@"?
Hm, but there is one more issue: when compiling with "javac -g" we'd have constructor parameter names embedded in .CLASS. Why Eclipse is not retrieving at least constructor argument names?

bug.short_desc: web library is packaged as war inside war

long_desc.thetext:
1. Create dynamic web project, add it to EAR. 2. Create any ejb project (no matter in EAR or not) 3. Open web project properties, 4. Go to section "J2EE Module Dependencies" 5. Open tab "Web Libraries" 6. Check ejb module.
Build all, deploy on Weblogic 9.0 server. Look in ear in autodeploy directory. It contains war inside, and war contains inside one more war with the same name (containing ejb module contents)

This looks like a server framework packaging bug that was fixed (I just tried it with 1.5.2 and things were packaged correctly) - Gorkem, sending your way to verify that this represents a known/fixed issue.
yep looks like the old bug. Can you please try 1.5.2

bug.short_desc: Threaded update process

long_desc.thetext: During the update process, a significant amount of time seems to be spent waiting for the update sites to respond or to find the mirrors associated with a particular feature. Additionally, downloads can often be slow because the server providing the data is busy (especially shortly after a new release). Running the queries in parallel rather than sequentially could save a significant amount of time, assuming the bottle neck is the server, and not the client.

Created an attachment (id=56136) Threads the feature download process, first attempt This is a pretty naive attempt at threading the feature download process. The path includes code that will download all features selected by the user concurrently. It also has code to download the individual archives concurrently, but that's probably overkill, since they will likely come from the same server. I started to work on code to select mirror sites concurrently as well, but I ran into some trouble with the static classes/methods being used to find mirrors. However, that process often appears to take a good deal of time, so a concurrent implementation might help.

The progress info shown to the user with this approach leaves something to be desired. ("User operation is waiting for background operationds to compelte").

I also had to modify the version number of the plugin.xml file in order for this to run from the workbench. That didn't seem like the right thing to do, but this is my first attempt at a patch.

attachment.desc: Threads the feature download process, first attempt

Something like this
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <site pack200="true" digestURL="http://download.eclipse.org/releases/europa" mirrorsURL="http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=releases/europa&format=xml"> </site>

bug.short_desc: content-format is required in repository descriptor.

long_desc.thetext:
After some discussion on dev list (liks below) we came into idea that we are missing one parameter in repository definition - content-format. This would define what is the format of information kept in the repository.
Example - a team member repository. - content-type holds information that repository keeps information about team members - content-format keeps information about format the team members are kept; it might be XML in Corona format, XML in Compuware format or JDBC in format of Company X. - access-type holds information about storage: file in CVS, WebDAV, etc.
So far content-format was merged into either content-type or access-type.
See mailing list threads (for some reason there are only 2-3 emails per thread even though they are in a single thread): http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/corona-dev/msg00610.html http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/corona-dev/msg00616.html http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/corona-dev/msg00623.html http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/corona-dev/msg00625.html http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/corona-dev/msg00627.html

The biggest question is when should it be done? - we have already to many tasks for M7 - in February two of us are going for 2 week holiday (me and Piotr) - in March we need to have an API freeze, if we want to be in Europa

According to Europa guidelines we have API freeze on Apr 6.
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Europa_Simultaneous_Release
we have changed the model and these types of properties can easily be added into the properties map of the new Corona EMF model

bug.short_desc: [Doc] Document behaviour of pluginPath

long_desc.thetext:
For building our RCP application we are using eclipse ant script productBuild.xml.
In our case plugin directory is not a sub directory of the buildDirectory.
While building an RCP application from a product configuration file. my buildDirectory=D:/newfolder/build and I have specified the optional parameter for eclipse.generateFeature pluginPath=D:/project/plugins;${baseLocation}
But while running the productbuild.xml its not recognizing the plugin path ie. I am getting an error saying the plugin is missing.
This bug has been posted last month and can I know whether any solution could be given.

Change your property to pluginPath=C:/project;${baseLocation} (Or simply pluginPath=C:/project, the ${baseLocation} is redundant if it was already specified to the baseLocation parameter).
The pluginPath entries must either point directly to a plugin (jar or folder), or to the parent of the plugins directory. For pluginPath = D:\project if D:\project\plugins exists, then we add all the jars & directories in D:\project\plugins. Otherwise we add the single directory D:\project as a plugin.
Docs doesn't really have any details on this, we should update them. Similarily, when looking for features, we will look in D:\project\features or D:\project directly.
point of reference: it is not clear we should commit to this api. If you do doc it, please ensure it is appropriately annotated wrt API.
In fact this was already documented.

If you use the symlink .../JavaVM.framework/Versions/CurrentJDK/Commands/java for the -vm arg, then it will use whatever is considered to be the Current JDK on the system. bug.short_desc: [preferences] allow users to automatically load externally changed file

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: Version 3.2.0 M20060629-10-5
Steps To Reproduce: 1. enable "Refresh automatically" 2. open a file in an editor 3. edit this file externally and save it -> editor shows the changes automatically 4. edit this file a second time and save it -> editor does not show the changes 5. go with mouse onto Eclipse editon -> Eclipse asks "file has changed ..." Then behaviour continues with point 3.
More information: every other time, Eclipse asks for confirmation - that's a bug.
BTW. One should be able to specify "auto-reverse" on a file basis!

I cannot reproduce step 4 i.e. that works for me. NOTE: the auto-refresh mechanism is not live i.e. it runs from time to time and hence you might have hit before it ran.
>BTW. One should be able to specify "auto-reverse" on a file basis! Do you really need this on a per file basis? Wouldn't it be good enough never to ask if "Refresh automatically" is checked? Of course there would always be a dialog for dirty files.

> I cannot reproduce step 4 i.e. that works for me. NOTE: the auto-refresh > mechanism is not live i.e. it runs from time to time and hence you might have > hit before it ran.
You are right! I'm just too fast. But then Eclipse should simply refresh a file (if auto-refresh is on) in case if there is a difference between its version in the editor and on disc.
> Wouldn't it be good enough never to ask if "Refresh automatically" is > checked? Of course there would always be a dialog for dirty files.
Sorry, I don't understand this comment.
I'd like to see "Refresh automatically" on a file-by-file basis because normally I'd like to know if "something" changes my files. Only for some exceptional files, e.g. logfiles, I know in advance that it is allright.
>Sorry, I don't understand this comment. Exactly what you wrote in the first paragraph of comment 2 ;-)

> Wouldn't it be good enough never to ask if "Refresh automatically" is > checked?
That would be almost all the way. But see my last paragraph of comment #2.
> Of course there would always be a dialog for dirty files.
But if "Refresh automatically" is globally active (i.e., for all files) what then is a "dirty file" (in comparison to a "normal file" that has been changed externally)?

(In reply to comment #4)
> > Of course there would always be a dialog for dirty files. > > But if "Refresh automatically" is globally active (i.e., for all files) what > then is a "dirty file" (in comparison to a "normal file" that has been changed > externally)?
please ignore my last comment. Sorry.
If you want both then you need two bug reports ;-)

(In reply to comment #6) > If you want both then you need two bug reports ;-)
No, I don't want to ask for too much.
> Wouldn't it be good enough never to ask if "Refresh automatically" is > checked? Of course there would always be a dialog for dirty files.
That would be perfect.
Ulrich
OK then. Since this mainly applies to the textual editors I move this to Platform Text.

On a closer look we cannot reuse the existing preference because - it is on a different layer and - a user might want to disable auto-referesh of the workspace but have the content of editors updated automatically
*** Bug 174146 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 174252 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Another problem is that the refresh might have not yet been processed when switching back and hence you might get unexpectedly asked when saving the file.
What if the file in Eclipse is dirty?

I don't think this necessarily needs to apply to just text editors, but certainly it might make sense to implement it for these to start.
I think that the behaviour if the editor is dirty is to do the same in Eclipse at the moment -- that is, don't prompt for changes (but maybe report that the file is out of sync when saving).
PS for reference, NetBeans 5.5 and IntelliJ 6.0 automatically reload changes in editors made outside the IDE when the editor is activated. I can check what happens in the dirty situation. It was pleasantly surprising to do some changes and see them automatically updated -- I can understand how a user coming from one of those to Eclipse would be frustrated.
PPS if a new preference is enabled, then having a 'Do this from now on' checkbox on the dialog would also be a good place to enable the user to make the change.
PPPS can I help out with providing a patch for this?

>I don't think this necessarily needs to apply to just text editors, but >certainly it might make sense to implement it for these to start. Agree. Hence Platform UI (or IDE) should offer that preference and once it is there editors can start to adopt it - textual editors being the first ones. ==> moving to Platform UI to add such a preference.
I'm moving this back to UI to provide such a preference on the 'General' > 'Editors' preference page.
>I think that the behaviour if the editor is dirty is to do the same in Eclipse >at the moment -- that is, don't prompt for changes That's not how text editors currently behave. They always prompt if you activate an editor that operates on a out-of-sync file. And I think this should even be done if the preference is enabled because when we do it on save the user might have lost the context already.
>I can check what happens in the dirty situation. Yes please.
>It was pleasantly surprising to do some changes >and see them automatically updated Eclipse editors do that too if 1. the file in eclipse is not dirty 2. the save outside eclipse is recognized and sent as resouce delta by Platform Core before the user (too quickly ;-) switches back
>PPS if a new preference is enabled, then having a 'Do this from now on' >checkbox on the dialog would also be a good place to enable the user to make >the change. +1
>PPPS can I help out with providing a patch for this? I think if Platform UI agrees to provide the preference then this would be a nice spot for providing the patch. I can then add adopt in in Platform Text.
Boris, I added you since you've been in the code most recently but I've assigned it to Duong since he's the component owner...
We are interested in looking at a patch if anyone would like to contribute one.

I'd like to support reopening/assigning this bug. For my usage -- examining the output of an executable -- it is unworkable to the extent that I am having to write code that sends file to console to avoid clicking through these dialogs. I might suggest finer-grain control, that is you could set a file type or working set only to be auto-refresed.
if you submit a patch we would be happy to review it

Hi,
As I had stated earlier, it seems there is some environmental issue.
Just to verify, you have tried with the Windows XP fire wall turned off?
Also, are you operating on a corporate network? If so, is there anything special with the network as far as fire walls, proxie servers, etc.?
I might be helpful if I can look at some details just to eliminate various possibilities. Can you send to me in an email or preferably attach to this defect the workspace you created for this test so I can look at the details?
I am out on vacation the rest of the year. However, I will try to keep up with this defect during that time.
All this stuff has been around a long-time and basically works for most folks the first time around. I'm sure we will find the answer to this and appreciate your patience.
DuWayne

Thanks Robert

Hi again!
I think I'm doing something wrong. When I select Run>Debug.. I must, in the new configuration for Java Application, choose a Main class. When I click Search button appears a list with some classes. I don't know wich of them I must use. I thought that it wasn't very important but choosing one or another the error message changes.
I'm sorry but I am very lost now. I don't know what to do.
Thank you very much robert

It would seem that you would benefit from a good book on using Eclipse and/or perhaps following some tutorials. I am sorry, but I do not have enough free time to work indirectly through the bugzilla mechanism to teach how to use the Eclipse IDE.
Also, I am repeating the statement that you never did answer my previous questions about your network environment other than to say you don't have a firewall running on your machine. ("Also, are you operating on a corporate network? If so, is there anything special with the network as far as fire walls, proxie servers, etc.?").
Once you get to the point where you are up and running with further useful information, I will be happy to assist in finding the problem with running a URL test.

Hi again
I'm sorry, I have been working with TPTP during a month with christmas holidays inside. I follow the tutorial at the begining and I have forgotten some basical rules. I have been following some tutorials again.
I'm sorry for don't answer your question exactly too. I'm on a corporate network which uses proxy. In others testing tools we have some problems with this because whe have the LAN configuration of the browser with automatic configuration. We solve this problem with the other tools introducing the IP address of the proxy server manually.
I have launched the program, this time correctly, and the only exception the program shows is
java.net.ConnectException: Connection timed out: connect
I think as you think, it must be a problem with proxy server but I don't know how to solve it. Maybe is a problem with my computer. I'm going to try to launch a test in another computer during this week. If I solve the problem I will say to you.
Thank you very much and sorry for the bothers Robert

Hi,
The problem is that we currently do not support URL test execution through a proxy server. That would be an enhancement request. It had been discussed at some point long ago. It was generally not thought to be a common use case and is problematic in the sense that any playback would be loading the proxy server as well as the system under test (SUT). If you wish, you may change this defect to an enhancement request.

Hi Robert,
I am resolving this defect as invalid. The remaining issue, URL Test Execution through a proxy server is currently not supported in TPTP. You may re-open and change this to an enhancement request if you wish to do so.
Regards, DuWayne
